Attractions.title: VENUE1
Attractions.paragraph: The world is constantly evolving, and with it, so are the ways in which we communicate. Technology has played a big role in shaping the way we interact with one another, from the way we send messages to the way we connect with people on the other side of the world. Social media has become a powerful tool for connecting people, but it also has its drawbacks. One of the biggest concerns is the impact it has on our mental health and well-being.

Testimonials.name: Nick lorem ipsum
Testimonials.comment: Dor ohur. Speras mikrong jepogt. Tångar nasam an. Emstat jyde. Are benar. Udås tåbel stenoligt. Märk-dna bida, polyrad. Lyssna in utsmarm än sad. Ressade bek antitism. . Matilda Gustavsson n

speakers.name: Maya Shavin
speakers.bio: Maya is Senior Software Engineer in Microsoft, working extensively with JavaScript and frontend frameworks and based in Israel. She founded and is currently the organizer of the VueJS Israel Meetup Community, helping to create a strong playground for Vue.js lovers and like-minded developers. Maya is also a published author, international speaker and an open-source library maintainer of frontend and web projects. As a core maintainer of StorefrontUI framework for e-commerce, she focuses on delivering performant components and best practices to the community while believing a strong Vanilla JavaScript knowledge is necessary for being a good web developer. She can be reached at her blog (https://mayashavin.com), on Twitter @mayashavin, or via email.
speakers.talkTitle: The art of visualization and composition in building component systems.
speakers.talkDescription: Let's face it, understanding a long page of specs is not always a trivial task to do. Same as building a complex component system. Let's explore how we can combine visualization and composition API to create our reusable and visual-able logic system for your components, ready to use in Vue application.

speakers.name: Tejas Kumar
speakers.bio: Tejas is an international Keynote speaker and software engineer who shares best practices with engineers.
speakers.talkDescription: 2022 saw the rise of new paradigms, from Qwik to SolidJS to SvelteKit 1.0. This talk explores the current and predicted state of frontend frameworks and enables engineers to be in the loop and make the best choice for their teams.

speakers.name: Roy Derks
speakers.bio: Roy is an entrepreneur, speaker and author from The Netherlands and, in his own words, 'wants to make the world a better place through tech'. He has been giving talks and training to developers worldwide on technologies like GraphQL, React and TypeScript. Most recently he wrote the books Fullstack GraphQL and React Projects.
speakers.talkDescription: Let's face it, there are many advantages to using GraphQL compared to REST APIs. But if you strip it down to the network protocol, it's using HTTP just as REST. We developers need to write a lot of imperative code to retrieve data to display in our applications and handle state. With GraphQL you can, when using the correct libraries, decrease the amount of code needed around data fetching and state-management. Next to increased flexibility, better performance and most of all an improved developer experience. In this talk I show GraphQL's magic and how (in the end) it's just HTTP.
speakers.Technologies: GraphQL, JavaScript, Data fetching, state management

speakers.name: Keren Kenzi
speakers.bio: Keren is a full-stack developer at Torii, who has been working as a software engineer for more than a decade. She has a M.Sc. in Computer Science and loves React and learning new technologies. Keren volunteers as a program manager at Baot, a community that helps women in tech in their professional growth. She is also a dev community leader and co-organizes meetups. And in her not-so-spare time, she studies psychology. Her hobbies include drawing, photography, and singing.
speakers.talkDescription: There is a saying that the best way to learn something is to teach it to someone else. When we write a tech blog, we share our knowledge with others and deepen our understanding of the subject. We also improve other skills along the way and build our professional brand and signature.In this talk, we will discuss the benefits of writing a blog and try to remove all the barriers that have stopped us so far from writing a blog.

speakers.name: Marek Kirejczyk
speakers.bio: Enthusiast of technology, programming, and managing technology teams. Creator of the open-source libraries Waffle and useDApp popular in the Blockchain and Ethereum environment. Founder of well-known Polish software houses Ethworks and El Passion, which he successfully exited. Currently, he is taking a one-year break from work.
speakers.talkDescription: Unveiling the secrets of successful project delivery: Discover three overlooked yet powerful techniques that can help you overcome common challenges faced by CTOs, Agile coaches, and DevOps teams. Learn how to deliver on time, foster positive relationships with stakeholders, and avoid project failure with these easy-to-implement tricks.

speakers.name: Yonatan Kra
speakers.bio: Yonatan has been involved in some awesome projects in the academy and the industry - from C/C++ through Matlab to PHP and javascript. Former CTO at Webiks and Software Architect at WalkMe. Currently he is a software architect at Vonage and an egghead instructor.
speakers.talkDescription: What can software developers learn from doctors, scientists and martial artists? During my years as a developer I’ve written lots of software. Ranging from data related like image processing, sound analysis and synthesis, and data analysis to working on fullstack web applications.I’ve picked up some skills in various fields like performance, design patterns and devops. In this talk I’m going to share with you the one thing that makes me a better developer than my younger self - automated tests. You will learn how tests can improve your code, how to write better tests, how to use code coverage and how it is all related to medicine, housekeeping work and martial arts.

speakers.name: Malwina Kubas
speakers.bio: Malwina is the Co-founder and CTO of ec0lint - a tool for frontend developers that mitigates the carbon footprint of websites. On top of that, she works as a Full-Stack Developer with technologies like JavaScript, TypeScript, React and Java. Malwina's interests are leadership and project management.
speakers.talkTitle: Digital ecology: How can you mitigate the carbon footprint of websites?
speakers.talkDescription: Did you know that about 250 000 websites are published every day? The majority uses too heavy fonts, unnecessary images or utilises redundant libraries generating carbon footprint. ec0lint is a tool for frontend developers that mitigates the carbon footprint of websites by showing tips on how to create a more climate-friendly code. Thanks to code optimization ec0lint can help in reducing emissions from 1.8 g to ~0.2 g per one view saving 216 kg CO2 for each website (-88%!) annually.

speakers.name: Ankita Kulkarni
speakers.bio: Ankita is a Senior Engineering Technical Leader with over a decade of Tech industry experience. She is currently an Educator and creates digital products such as her [E-book](http://bit.ly/3grSPSI) on taking control of your first 90 days, best suited for newer leaders or her [course](http://bit.ly/3tUPRcr) on Next.js. She is passionate about growing developers and leaders. She worked for several companies such as WealthSimple, IBM, Loblaw Digital - ShoppersDrugMart, Rangle.io and more. As a senior leader, she has grown a lot of folks in her career, and her mission is to help mentor folks in all stages of their career. She has architected and scaled many web and mobile apps for clients using React, GraphQL, React Native and Next.js. You may know some of them: Tim Hortons, Burger King, Popeyes, Borrowell, WealthSimple, Moleskine and more. She enjoys teaching, public speaking and being outdoors
speakers.talkTitle: ## **Building a lightning-fast site with Next.js, GraphQL and Tailwind
speakers.talkDescription: Next.js has grown in popularity over the past couple of years with features like server-side rendering, incremental static regeneration, image optimization, and more. In contrast, GraphQL is known for not just returning data for what you need with good schema design practices but also a good dev experience.In this talk, I’ll talk about how one can build an app that not just scales but also has high performance with Next.js, GraphQL and Tailwind. And Lastly, the future of CSS and Frontend development is building utilities, so CSS does not feel like an afterthought. At the end of this talk, you will learn how to go from making a sample app to a highly performant production-ready application.

speakers.name: Nir Kaufman
speakers.bio: Frontend developer,community enthusiast, meetup organizer, international public speaker, trainer, author, and mentor, Google developer expert in web technologies. When I'm not coding I produce electronic music, and vegan food.
speakers.talkTitle: Classic design patterns for the modern JS developer
speakers.talkDescription: In this session we will learn how and why classic software design patterns are relevant for the modern frontend developer - and how to leverage then for everyday challenges.All with live coding examples based on real world use-cases
